I love having the New Yorker content in an app, but the design of this app tries too hard to be different. Some examples:
1. When I single-tap while in the app, I expect to see the iOS top bar w/ the clock, battery life, etc. Having to exit the app just to check the time is distracting & annoying.
2. Support the "double-tap at the top to scroll up" feature. When I get to the end of an article, I often want to scroll back to the top to see the author's name or the article photo. Having to scroll back up through 51 pages of article kills the thumbs.
3. Why do short articles scroll normally, but long articles scroll in pages? Just let everything scroll normally - the paging feels too short anyway.
4. For articles that page, that center-bottom "Share" menu is such a distraction. Show it only on single-tap - there's no reason to waste screen space displaying it all the time.
5. Support iPhone 5 already!

I wasn't sure if it was going to be worth the $20, but it is, without a doubt! The game is challenging, interesting, and beautiful. There is no doubt in my mind that this is a console quality game on mobile devices, and worth every penny.

That said, it strains any device using an A5 processor to its absolute limits. I'm playing on an iPad mini and I can tell its working hard. While it runs very well, with minimal frame rate drops or skipping in cut scenes, it would certainly be better on an iPad using the A6X processor. Though it might be possible to play this on an iPhone 5, I would recommend it. I haven't tried it on mine, but there's so much going on that you will need the additional screen space.

Going hand-in-hand with the resource intensity is the enormous batter drain. I get GREAT battery life on my iPad mini (~10 hrs) and this is just burning through the charge. Playing today for about 2 hours took me from ~50% to 10%.

Another warning: turn off your notifications before you play on A5 device. It booted me out of the game and I lost some (but not much) progress in a mission. I'm not sure how often it auto-saves, locally or to the cloud, but I'm certainly glad that it does.

The bottom line is that this a great game and well worth the price. Buy it and be happier for having done so.

Enjoy!

Found is a great search app, easily accessed by double-tapping the "control" key. Searching across services like Google Docs and Gmail attachments is an extra bonus.

BUT... running Found causes my MacBook Pro to switch from the battery-saving integrated graphics adapter to the power-hungry discrete graphics adapter. This impacts battery life considerably, and makes the "launch at login" option an unwise choice. So it's something you have to remember to start. Then, when you're on battery, you have to remember to open the Found window, click the Settings icon, and then click the "Quit Found" button, which is somewhat tedious... and there doesn't appear to be any other way to easily quit the app (by clicking on its menu bar icon to display a menu, for example.)

I'm not sure what the developer can do to address the discrete graphics requirement, but until the issue is addressed, I would recommend that people with a MacBook do not leave it running all the time.

This is a cool app that works great on the iPhone 5s. It harnesses the M7 on the phone so it doesn't drain the battery like other fitness/pedometer apps that use GPS. It was interesting to load the app for the first time and watch as it downloaded my steps for the last week.

My only complaint is that it doesn't include any means of calorie tracking (along the lines of myFitnessPal). The only food feature is the ability to take pictures of the food you're about to eat.

For those saying it runs GPS constantly so it kills your battery, it was optimized for the M7 chip in the 5S. When you have a 5S it works in the background and my battery life hasn't taken a hit.

I like it. It's a cool way to track my health related activities. When I first installed it the app pulled up the last seven days of the steps I've taken. I assume it pulled the info off of the M7 chip, which tells me that the M7 logs info whether or not an app requires it, since a argus was the first app that did. That also tells me that argus shouldn't affect battery life by using the M7 either.

For users having issues with battery life you should know that ios7 has many settings that can effect the longevity of your battery. If you just updated to ios7 without checking into these settings then you are missing out. You can set which apps use gps, which apps continue working in the background when you aren't using them, and whether or not your apps update automatically. All of these things can drain your battery when you don't want them to.

Lastly, I subtracted one star from Argus because to get the full functionality that Argus offers you need a few more certain apps that each cost a few more dollars. One for the heart rate monitor (which is pretty cool BTW), one for measuring your workouts (called Instant Fitness), and one for tracking your sleep (I don't think it's necessary). You can enter the measurements that these extra apps record manually but I don't know how to figure out the measurements without the apps beyond just a vague guess. Also you can buy a $150 weight scale that syncs information with Argus if you want. F that I say!

TLDR: I like Argus. It's cool. I think I'll be using it for a while.
